There's a common misinterpretation of how many segments this film has.  It actually only has three; The Dawn of Man, Jupiter Mission: 18 Months Later, and finally Jupiter and Beyond the Infinite. This divides the movie into three sections, not the commonly believed 4 sections. What's more important here is that Kubrick (and editor Ray Lovejoy) have told the audience that despite technological advances, the dawn of humanity and it's future self has not evolved as much as we think in those 4 million years of evolution.  That hard jump-cut between bone and spacecraft compresses the ancient with the future into one section.

Interesting, yet the story is Clarke's and his novel has a very precise explanation of everything. For example the whole thing with HAL has almost nothing to do with the central story, it's just a malfunction due to conflicting programming, since the computer was supposed to be truthful, yet was given a secret mission which it could not disclose. The fact that this part of the story is given so much prominence in the movie actually shows they needed to give more space to something thriller-like. And the marketing department used it to attract viewers to the "rogue computer" story, even though it's the least thought provoking idea from the whole story. I think saying "nothing here is an accident, everything was intentional" might be overstating it. Saying that bad dialogue is intentional because of some deep reason is just alibism. I think the choice to display technology instead of developing characters was because they simply wanted to make a visually stunning movie and wanted to showcase technological visions. Besides, Clarke generally leaned more to world-building or "technology-building" in his books and his characters seemed to get somewhat less important and repetitive. Anyway, I have no doubt the story is predominantly Clarke's and I don't think Kubrick did it justice in the movie. I think that with some of the scenes being very protracted, there was enough space to give more attention to the story and its cohesion while still keeping the overall artistic impact. Lastly - if you say you think it's perfect and exactly as intended, I think you're wrong. I don't believe it happens often that a movie director says their movie came out exactly as they wanted. Or they may say that for publicity purposes, but think differently. I'm not in film, but I'm pretty sure compromises have to be made, shots don't work out the way they ideally should, something has to be edited out etc. etc.. That makes reading meaning into every little detail somewhat pointless, because some of those details must be completely unintentional.

Most of the questions you bring up are answered pretty blatantly (even repeatedly) in the book. Unlike Kubrick, Clarke seems not at all interested in his readers scratching their heads not understanding what just happened in the story they read. You can say "The movie isn't the book!" but in this case, it kind of is. Despite any discrepancies (such as Saturn vs. Jupiter) the basic events and themes are the same. They even developed the story together, and tried to coordinate the 2 so the book would come out slightly earlier. But then Kubrick changed his mind (back and forth) about some stuff and couldn't figure out how to do other stuff without making it look like sci-fi schlock. So the movie came out first, and the book was treated as a novelization of a movie instead of the other way around.

For instance: The Dawn of Man monolith was basically a transparent teaching machine in the book. It was not there to bear witness to human evolution, but to fast forward it. There were "scores" of them all over the planet while their makers (who were still "flesh and blood" at that point) hovered in orbit for years. They consider intelligence the one truly valuable commodity in the universe, so they set out to advance it in every place they thought they could, cultivating it like a crop. And these teaching machines didn't single out the primates because they thought they were super special. it's just that they happen to be the subjects who performed the most promisingly on this particular life-breeding planet.

One small detail which takes the monolith concept further is that the movie opens with a black screen for several minutes and ends with a black screen for several minutes after the ends credits stopped rolling where only music is heard.  Its almost as if we as the audience are looking into the monolith DURING THE ENTIRE MOVIE experiencing FIRSTHAND the progression and evolution of the human species.

The monolith is intelligence personified, when anything touches it, it jumps to the next evolution and understanding of the universe, which in itself is intelligence. Intelligence and cosmos are not two different things. Just the human perspective differs.

I wonder if the opening black screen is an allusion for empty space or the nothingness before the universe's inception... in any case I think the ambiguity of the film which allows the viewer's imagination to think and wonder is one of it's greatest assets. It makes you think rather than giving a straight answer. Where many films give all the information directly and don't require any further input or creative interpretation. 2001 let's you explore it's presented content with curiosity and a hunger to find meaning and conclusions on your own. The "gaps" it leaves out leads the mind into an exploratory and inquisitive framing. Similar to a child trying to understand the world, the film renders it's audience into the same state when they are trying to understand its world. In so doing, one could say it makes it's audience into active explorers instead of passive observers, and in my opinion that is what makes the movie a masterpiece.

There is a similarity or correspondence between Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" and Beethoven's 9'th Symphony, in their structure and emotional impact.  The opening of the 9'th Symphony is very "primordial", in the same way that the movie opens with the "dawn of Man".  The second movement of the 9'th Symphony evokes a sense of action and adventure, corresponding with the movie's journey into space and battle to survive HAL's rampage.  Next, the 9'th Symphony has a slow, perhaps sentimental movement, which is somewhat analogous to Dave living out the rest of his life in the white "alien room", as he reflects back on his memories.  Finally, the 9'th symphony ends with the glorious choral movement, with an ethereal choir exhorting us to seek out our creator "above the stars".  The movie ends with the birth of the "star baby", looking down on the Earth, perhaps exhorting us to transcend our corporeal lives for a more spiritual existence.  Also - and this is probably too much of a stretch - when Dave is living his final years in the white "alien room", he exists in almost total silence, which is very much like how Beethoven spent his final years, almost totally deaf.

If you read all the books, then you needn't speculate. Before his passing, Clarke was very specific about just what happened in the movie and the book for Dave Bowman. He became or was absorbed by, the Sentinel, as was HAL 9000. The Sentinel was a very complex and self aware machine but in a sense, not completely conscious. It's job was to warn it's creators of danger. And if we posed a danger to the local galactic neighborhood, it was expected to destroy us, entirely. Dave Bowman and HAL became a sort of digital backup of what they once were, and in a sense, died and their minds were absorbed by the Sentinel, and given a sort of existence, plain and 'pre-recorded' as it may have been. In the subsequent movies, Dave visits his former wife and explains this to her, remarking that he could not even explain his current form nor his 'type' of consciousness, even if he wanted to. But he was aware enough to 'desire' closure with her.


So, Kubrick's interpretation of Clarke's ideas were the best visual attempt at describing Dave Bowman being absorbed by the Sentinel but being allowed to see a possible future and what he would have been and done had he been able to return to earth and live out his life. It was almost an insult in a way, as the Sentinel gave him a glimpse, then killed him by absorption, then integrated his mind into itself so it could understand humanity, better. In essence, scientific vivisection. Yipes.

I read many people who say how the monolith came about. Here's some facts. The first intent was to have the monolith as a triangular solid, but it didn't look impressive. Then it was to be a rectangular TV screen where images appeared to teach the ape men. This was rejected as being too obvious. Finally, they settled on the 2-4-9 ratio rectangle in black as being the most mysterious and impressive looking. In his book, Clarke says the 2-4-9 ratio were the squares of numbers in three dimensions, but the squares continued into higher dimensions that we can't see.

Despite it being a great film, I think it's misguided to say that "this is what space travel will be like." This is probably the biggest problem with the film. It won't be like this. It would take way too much money and time to build all the things you see in the movie. I think they extrapolated from bus, to train, to plane, to space. The problem is, you run out of time and money between the last two. And many things aren't right. The crescent in the opening sequence is too thick. The sun would be absolutely blinding. The stars wouldn't be continuously moving up (or was it down?) when Frank was drifting out into space, unless the camera was orbiting him. Lots of things like this. I catch more every time I see it. And HAL. Who has a yellow light inside his eye? Eyes don't contain lights. His does. And why not two of them for stereoscopic vision? There are many more things like this. Oh, and the big cavern for the spaceship descending into the moon. Why do you need this huge cavern? It would take decades to build it. And what's the bit with no HAL 9000 ever making an error. Uh, it was humans who built and programmed the thing. They can't be error-prone and error-free at the same time!


As for explaining what's happening, as I said in another comment: it's basically like you're a fly on the wall. No one knows you're there. You are purely just an observer. No "exposition."

The one thing Kubrick himself has said, is that he's made all of his films to be experienced on a personal level. He gives the audience enough details, with which the audience member then interprets things for themselves based on what they've been shown. It's a very American problem, where people often have problems with films when they aren't spoon fed every emotion they're supposed to feel and what they're supposed to think. To be fair, it's quite respectful of Kubrick to enable people to have their own experience of his films. I can look back at all of the films I've considered to be excellent or of high quality and recall that my experience of those films were very powerful and personal. Which is what makes Kubrick a master film maker.

Around the seventh time I watched this (amazing) movie, I had one insight that I think is more in tune with the core of the movie philosophy: the "monolith" shown in the picture is not necessarily what it appears to be. Instead it is a metaphor for "knowledge". As it happens in many discoveries, you look many, many, many times at something and see nothing. The information you need is like a blank space, or a censoring black strip, or a dark monolith. Then one day you look at it and finally see what you need to see and from that moment on, you can never unsee it.

Very insightful. However, I want to change one thing. When the man-ape ("Moonwatcher" as he is called in the book) throws the bone up into the air and we then get that amazing segue shot what we then see is not some benign "spacecraft" in orbit. According to the book it is actually a nuclear weapons platform capable of enormous destruction. It seems that Kubrick is saying that after millions of years we are still a species capable of great violence and murder against our fellow "tribes". Also, in the book,when the Star Child returns to Earth and contemplates what to do there are alerts from the ground and these weapons platforms are prepared to be used against it. However, the Star Child eliminates them with a thought and, most evocatively, then proceeds to determine just what he is going to do with his former home. A very provocative ending from Arthur C. Clarke and one that paralleled his other books with their theme of human evolution, such as "Childhood's End".

This is a very good analysis of the film, however, by all accounts, the transition from the bone is not to a spacecraft, but to an orbiting nuclear weapon.  The point being, of course, that this transition represents the evolution of man as measured by the evolution of his weapons.  It makes sense to transition from weapon of the past to weapon of the future.  This may seem like a minor point but it does affect the analysis with respect to advancing to a more positive future,  In my opinion, it shows that while technology has evolved, man has not.  This seems to be at the core of what the movie addresses.  From that perspective, this transition in the movie is one of the most meaningful with respect to understanding the story.

I've always thought it was interesting that Kubrick doesn't quite show the monolith itself as a door. Clarke wrote it that way in the novel: it's standing on the surface of Iapetus, Dave tries to actually land on it and says "the thing is hollow, it goes on forever-- and, my God, it's full of stars".

But in the movie, that's not quite what happens. The camera shows the solid monolith among the Galilean moons, pans up into black space--and the bright colored lines of the Star Gate burst out from a point in empty space. I figure Kubrick might have been trying to keep the use of the monolith as Twilight Zone door from being too on the nose.

I don't consider 2001: A Space Odyssey a movie, but rather as a piece of art. A a traditional movie it has its fair share of shortcomings and when the movie was first released it was also critically slashed by most reviewers. As a piece of art 2001: A Space Odessey challenges the viewer to discover the story by visuals and scenes, not by words. An accomplishment very few movies can achieve.

That thing about conquering technology, it sounds wrong. Technology by definition is just the knowledge of techniques to be passed down through people, so you can't just "conquer" it. Even if you are some kind of divine being, a god for example, who can do make things happen at its will, you still need to think something in some way to do so, and that would be a technique.

In other words, if there's a thing you can do and you can describe how to do it, there's a technique and a technology.

I've always thought that 2001 the movie suffers slightly when you've read the novel counterpart, at last in my perspective. The issue isn't that the film isn't intellegent or that it didn't have interesting ideas, but that in comparison to the novel it's, well, kinda boring to me. The movie is so prone to long sequences that overstay there welcome just a bit too much, and the characters are so depthless that for me it lacks any element of humanity. You say in the video that this is part of the point of the movie, but unlike the book, the movie can't create a reaction out of me without these elements. The book has a very inviting narration style that gives the story some humanity, but the film just tries to compensate for this by adding in lots of beautiful shots, but these don't engage the audience. I know a lot of people love this movie, and good for you, I guess, but for me it's not even that I don't like it it's just that it provokes no reaction out of me, I don't feel anything or learn anything, so it fails as art to me, I'd rather just read a boring intellectual essay written by Kubrick, because that might as well be what this movie is. I guess others get a lot out of the cinematography and whatnot, I'll just always prefer the novel.

The relationship of the bone to the spaceship to which it transitions was more obvious in an early cut. The spaceship is actually an orbiting nuclear weapons platform. So we transition from humanity's first technological weapon to its latest and possibly last.

In the films original script there was a relevant subplot about the USSR and the USA being on the verge of nuclear war. At the end of the film nuclear missiles are indeed launched, but the Star Child detonates them before they can enter the atmosphere.

Those were among the changes that Kubrick made because he wanted "2001"to be more vague and less concerned with specifics. He wanted an experience over a typical narrative. He also downplayed the meaning of what Bowman sees as he enters the Monolith. In the novel that Clarke wrote concurrently to Kubrick shaping the script the are very specific details, including remnants from the evolution of the alien society that designed the Monoliths. That's part of what Bowman sees in his journey. I'm not saying that's better or worse than the approach of the movie. The book is a good science fiction novel in its own right and a quick read, but if the film had followed the same aesthetic it wouldn't be the classic it is.

Great review of one of the greatest films ever. However, I disagree with the idea that 2001 is a timeless piece of art.

On the contrary, it's very much a product of its time and place, the late 1960s. From the completely unrealistic and far too optimistic timeline of having bases on the moon and interplanetary travel by 2001, to the conflict between the US and the Soviet Union, (made clear in the movie that the rivalry between the two superpowers hadn't ended, and based upon the then current rivalry of the Space Race), to the "killer ape hypothesis" of human origins and evolution of man, 2001: A Space Odyssey reflects the then current level of understanding of technology, human origins, and current events of the 1960s.

It's the way in which Kubrick films and explicates these ideas that makes it so compelling to audiences even 50 years later.

One of my all time favourite movies! As a hard scifi nerd, I always get shivers when seeing those PERFECT space scenes. No sound, smooth trajectories, reaction control systems, centrifuges for artificial 'gravity', realistic deck layouts, coasting ships with rocket engines only firing when a burn is needed...why can't we have more of this instead of endless fighter planes and ocean liners in space (and yes, I know of the expanse). And what always amazes me, for a 50 year old movie it still looks so incredibly contemporary.

The one thing I can't agree with in this reviev / interpretation is the argument about abandoning technology. For me the monoliths always represented just that: technology. Just another kind of tool, far more advanced than ours, made by beings equally far more advanced. As Arthur C. Clarke said: "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic." And so as spaceships would have seemed like magic to those man-apes, higher-dimensional transport and ultimately state of being might seem phantastical to us. So Bowman's ascension, for me, was a kind of uplifting to a higher dimensional plane, perhaps joining the (artificial) intelligence of the monolith.

But then again, there'll always be controversy and debate when discussing the interpretations of this masterpiece :D

Stanley Kubrick was one of the best directors of cinema history that has ever lived and this is his most representative work of art of the genius he was. Fifty years later, he continues to cause controversy and place new questions in his films, which are left to interpretation and have open endings. 2001: A Space Odyssey belongs to a category of superior cinema to almost any other and has the honor of literally being one of the best films of all time, of using a new way of narrating an epic story and of revolutionizing the genre, influencing hundreds of filmmakers in the future. Glory on the screen, and a feast for the senses, 2001: A Space Odyssey is the definitive masterpiece of a genius, and a rather interesting comment of what we are and represent, and the meaning of life itself.
